Term.Name: Methodist
Term.Definition: Followers of John and Charles Wesley who tried to reform the Church of England in the 18th century and turned into a separate church

Term.Name: Baptist
Term.Definition: Members of a christian church which only baptises adults who truly believe in Christ

Term.Name: Mennonite
Term.Definition: Members of a 16th century christian church which is against military service and baptising infants

Term.Name: Mormon
Term.Definition: Members of a religious community which believes in the "Book of Mormon" and the revelations of founder M.J. Smith

Term.Name: Roman Catholic
Term.Definition: Biggest christian church worldwide tracing its origins back to Jesus Christ
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Old Catholic
Term.Definition: Members of a catholic church which started in 1870 and denies the dogma of the infallibility of the pope
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Orthodoxy
Term.Definition: Eastern rite churches which are characterised by their continuity with the apostolic church, their liturgy and their territorial churches, mainly in eastern and south-eastern Europe and the Middle East
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Parsasm

Term.Definition: Individual mountain bike race against the clock staged on a downhill circuit featuring obstacles.

Term.Definition: A timed race in which competitors on mountain bikes must negotiate tricky terrain and obstacles without putting their feet down.

Term.Definition: Two cyclists or teams set off from midway down opposite straights and try to make up the gap between them over a distance of 4000 m.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Individual pursuit
Term.Definition: Two cyclists of competing teams set off from midway down opposite straights and try to make up the gap between them over a distance of 4000 m.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Olympic sprint
Term.Definition: Qualifying race held over 200m. From the quarter-finals two cyclists go head-to-heads. By teams races consist of three cyclists from different countries.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sprint
Term.Definition: Races between two cyclists over two or three laps, with a timed sprint finish over the last 200m.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Keirin
Term.Definition: Sprint between six cyclists where a pacemaker on a moped gradually increases the pace over the first 1400m. When the pacemaker leaves the track the race develops into a sprint finish over the final 6-700m.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Points race
Term.Definition: Cyclists aim to complete the highest number of laps. Bonus points are picked up in intermediate sprints held every 2500m.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Madison race
Term.Definition: A points race by teams comprising two cyclists in relay-format.

Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Definition: A Women only category. Similar to baseball but with a larger and softer ball, a thinner bat, shorter gaps between bases and less innings
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Volleyball
Term.Definition: Two teams of six record points by hitting a ball over a net into the opponent's half of the court, keeping it in the air at all times. Points are won when opponents fail to return the ball.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Beach volley
Term.Definition: Two teams of two players compete on a sand court. Unlike indoor volleyball, points are scored only when the serving team wins a rally or forces an error. The sand surface makes it more physically demanding than volleyball.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Frisbee

Term.Name: Ultimate
Term.Definition: Team game. Played outdoors on soccer-size field with 7 players per team and indoors with 5 players per team. Games are played to a preset number of goals. Goals are scored by passing the disc to a team-member catching it inside the goal area.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Guts
Term.Definition: Team game where two teams of 5 players each face each other. Teams take turns to throw the disc towards the other team. Points are scored if the opposing team does not catch the disc.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Overall
Term.Definition: Not an event in itself but in most competitions with individual events the winner of the competition will be awarded to the player with the highest combined score in the events.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Distance
Term.Definition: The object is to throw the disc as far as possible. Each player get five throws per turn. Throws are made downwind. World record is over 200 meters.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Discathon
Term.Definition: The object is to throw and run a park course of about 1 kilometre. Four players compete in each heat. They have two discs each. They may also carry a third disc in reserve. Where one thrown disc stops the second disc must be thrown.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: DDC
Term.Definition: Abbreviation for Double Disc Court. Two players per team in a square 13x13 metre. The teams start with one disc per team and throw at each other. Discs are thrown back and forth until one or both hit the ground.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: SCF
Term.Definition: Abbreviation for Self Caught Flights. Divided into two sub events called MTA (Maximum Time Aloft) and TRC (Throw Run Catch). In both sub events the player throws a disc and then runs to catch it with one hand before it hits the ground.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Freestyle
Term.Definition: A judged event where groups of two or three players perform as many tricks as possible. In competitions the judges can use either a ranking system or set scores on presentation, execution and difficulty.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Accuracy
Term.Definition: Each player has 28 throws from various distances and angles to throw the disc through a goal 1.5 x 1.5 meters. World record is 25 of 28 possible.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Disc golf
Term.Definition: Much like golf but played with discs instead of balls and clubs. Instead of a hole in the ground there is a metal basket with light metal chains to throw the disc at. Players often carry discs specialized for long throws, right or left bends.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Kabadi

Term.Name: Balkline
Term.Definition: A balkline is a line parallel to one end of a billiards table. Balk spaces define areas of the table surface in which a player may only score up to a threshold number of points while the object balls are within that region.

Term.Name: Three-cushion
Term.Definition: Requires a player to make contact with the other two balls on the table and contact three rail cushions in the process.

Term.Name: Artistic billiard
Term.Definition: Each set shot has a maximum point value assigned for perfect execution, ranging from a 4-point maximum for lowest level difficulty shots, and climbing to an 11-point maximum for shots deemed highest in difficulty level.

Term.Name: Fronton
Term.Definition: The "fronton" known as "Fronton Place Libre" consists of a rectangular outdoor court plus a large pink shaped wall at one end. The two sides and the other end are left opened.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Left wall
Term.Definition: A "fronton with left hand wall" is an indoor fronton with a 36 meters long court where Pala or Main Nue are played. Three walls are used in the game: the front, the back and the left hand wall.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Trinquet
Term.Definition: A "Trinquet" is an indoor fronton with a 28.5 meters long court surrounded by four walls. The four walls are used in the game.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Rebot
Term.Definition: The "rebot" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with 5 players in each team. They use a "chistera" (56 cm long and 12 cm large) or bare hands.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Chistera ancha
Term.Definition: The "chistera-ancha" also called the "cesta punta" is the game played in a "jaï alai" with 1 or 2 players in each team. The players use a long curved basket called the "chistera" (68 cm long and 13 cm wide).
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Chistera corta
Term.Definition: The "chistera-corta" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with left hand wall and 3 players in each team. The players use a long curved basket called the "chistera" (56 cm long and 12 cm wide).
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Bare hand
Term.Definition: The "Main Nue" (bare hand) is the ancestor of all Basque sports.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Pala-ancha
Term.Definition: The "pala-ancha" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with 2 players in each team. The players use a heavy wooden bat "the pala" (50 cm long and 20 cm wide).
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Pala-corta
Term.Definition: The "pala-corta" is the game played in a fronton with left hand wall and 2 players in each team. The players use a heavy wooden bat the "pala-corta" (50 cm long and 10 cm wide). The "pala" is the name for a heavy wooden bat.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Pasaka
Term.Definition: The "pasaka" is the name of the game played in a trinquet by teams of 2 players facing each other on each side of a net where the pelota is hit between opponents.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Xare
Term.Definition: The "xare", is the name of the game played in a trinquet by teams of 2 players. The players use a "xare" (or the Argentina bat) 55 cm long and 16 cm wide.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML
